message.content: This question requires knowledge about how to test the durability or hardness of a mineral. To determine the durability of a mineral, one could attempt to leave a mark on it. This is known as the scratch test. Different minerals have different levels of hardness, and if a mineral can be scratched by another material, it indicates that the mineral is less durable. Option (A) is incorrect because crushing the mineral in a vise does not determine its durability. Option (B) is unrelated because the atomic weight of a mineral does not indicate its durability. Option (D) is irrelevant because melting the mineral down and pouring it does not provide any information about its durability.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the properties of minerals and how to test their durability. To discover how durable a certain mineral may be, one could attempt to leave a mark on it. This is known as a scratch test and is often done using a mineral known as a Mohs scale of hardness. By using various minerals with known hardness, one can determine the relative hardness of the mineral in question. Option (A) is incorrect because crushing it in a vise does not provide information about its durability. Option (B) is incorrect because the atomic weight of a mineral is not directly related to its durability. Option (D) is incorrect because melting it down and pouring it does not provide information about its durability.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the Mohs Scale of Hardness, which is used to measure the durability of minerals. Option (C) is the correct answer because one can attempt to leave a mark on the mineral by scratching it with another mineral of known hardness. If the mineral being tested is scratched, it indicates that it is less durable than the mineral used to scratch it. Option (A) is incorrect because crushing the mineral does not provide information about its durability. Option (B) is unrelated to the durability of minerals and instead refers to atomic weight, which is a different concept. Option (D) is also unrelated to the durability of minerals and instead refers to melting and pouring, which is a different process.

This question requires some knowledge about methods used to determine the durability of a mineral. One way to assess the durability of a mineral is by attempting to leave a mark on its surface. If the mineral is soft and easily scratched, it is not very durable. Option (A) is incorrect because crushing the mineral in a vise does not provide information about its durability. Option (B) is also incorrect because the atomic weight of a mineral has no direct correlation to its durability. Option (D) is incorrect because melting the mineral down and pouring it does not provide information about its durability, but rather its melting point and behavior when melted.

This question asks about a method to determine the durability of a mineral. When trying to determine the durability of a mineral, one can attempt to leave a mark on it. This is known as the hardness test and is done by using other known minerals of varying hardness to scratch the surface of the mineral in question. If the mineral is easily scratched, it is considered less durable. Option (A) is incorrect as crushing the mineral in a vise does not provide information about its durability. Option (B) is unrelated to durability as atomic weight is not indicative of a mineral's durability. This question requires some knowledge about how to determine the durability or hardness of a mineral. One common method is to attempt to leave a mark on it using another mineral or object with known hardness, such as a fingernail or a steel nail. If the mineral is scratched or marked easily, it indicates that it has a lower hardness and is less durable. Option (A) is incorrect because crushing a mineral in a vise may determine its strength, but not necessarily its durability. Option (B) is incorrect because the atomic weight is not directly related to the durability of a mineral. Option (D) is incorrect because melting and pouring a mineral does not provide information about its durability.

This question requires knowledge of how to test the durability of a mineral. One way to do this is by attempting to leave a mark on the mineral. If the mineral is softer than the material used to test it (such as a fingernail or a piece of glass), a mark will be left. If the mineral is harder, it will not leave a mark. Options (A), (B), and (D) are incorrect because they do not accurately assess the durability of a mineral. Crushing it in a vise may provide information about its strength, but not its durability. Viewing the atomic weight of the mineral is unrelated to its durability. Melting it down and pouring it would provide information about its melting point and reactivity, but not its durability.

Option (A) is incorrect because crushing a mineral in a vise does not give information about its durability.
